sn46.14:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
sn46.14:4.2: Now at that time Venerable Mahākassapa was staying in the Pipphali cave, and he was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn46.14:4.3: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of solitude, went to Venerable Mahākassapa,
sn46.14:4.4: sat down on the indicated seat,
sn46.14:5.1: “Kassapa, I hope you’re keeping well; I hope you’re alright.
sn46.14:5.2: And I hope the pain is fading, not growing,
sn46.14:5.3: that its fading, not growing, is apparent.”
sn46.14:5.4: “Sir, I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright.
sn46.14:5.5: The pain is terrible and growing, not fading,
sn46.14:5.6: its growing, not fading, is apparent.”
sn46.14:6.1: “Kassapa, I’ve rightly explained these seven awakening factors. When developed and cultivated, they lead to direct knowledge, to awakening, and to extinguishment.
sn46.14:6.3: The awakening factors of mindfulness, investigation of principles, energy, rapture, tranquility, samādhi, and
sn46.14:6.5: These are the seven awakening factors that I’ve rightly explained. When developed and cultivated, they lead to direct knowledge, to awakening, and to extinguishment.”
sn46.14:6.6: “Indeed, Blessed One, these are awakening factors!
sn46.14:6.7: Indeed, Holy One, these are awakening factors!”
sn46.14:7.1: This is what the Buddha said.
sn46.14:7.2: Uplifted, Venerable Mahākassapa approved of what the Buddha said.
sn46.14:7.3: And that’s how he recovered from that illness.
